title: How to Make a Schedule and Stick to It

steps.title: Make a list of all the things you absolutely have to do during the day.
steps.content: Make a list of all the things you absolutely have to do during the day. This includes school, work, etc. These will be the things that have to be done at a certain time every day, and the times for which you do them cannot be moved around or rescheduled. Ideally, this list should be relatively short. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Make a list of things you do that need to be done.
steps.content: Make a list of things you do that need to be done. This includes exercising, studying, chores, shopping, personal hygiene, and so on. These are things that you need to do, but can be moved around a bit on your schedule for your convenience. [2] X Research source

steps.title: List all the things you would like to do, but are usually considered free time activities.
steps.content: List all the things you would like to do, but are usually considered free time activities. This includes reading, socializing, watching TV, video games, etc.

steps.title: Go through and fill in the tiny details of all of your daily activities.
steps.content: Go through and fill in the tiny details of all of your daily activities. For example, if you've written down "6:00 PM - Revision", turn it into "6:00 PM - Revision - Chapter 7 Science, make flashcards + review vocabulary". [3] X Research source

steps.title: Decide on the order of your daily activities.
steps.content: Decide on the order of your daily activities. Of course, go ahead and add all of step 1 activities first, then step 2's, and last but not least, step 3's. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Decide in what times of day you'll do each activity.
steps.content: Decide in what times of day you'll do each activity. Spending 1-2 hours per step 2 and 3-type activities is ideal, but do what's best for you. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Buy a planner/agenda/organizer.
steps.content: Buy a planner/agenda/organizer. After you have your ideal schedule in mind, you'll know what type of agenda is best for you. Remember, don't worry about what the cover of the planner looks like so much as if it has what you need in the contents on the inside. Worst case scenario, you could turn it into a DIY project if the cover isn't your style. Explore different layouts as not all planners are the same. There are different planners for different uses, so do your research. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Be realistic.
steps.content: Be realistic. Now that you've made your schedule, you're going to need to stick to it, which is going to be the most difficult part. You can't expect to cram 100 activities into 24 hours. If you have more activities to do than what you have time for, you have two options: Either have 2 different schedules that alternate between days (for example, Monday - Schedule 1, Tuesday - Schedule 2, Wednesday - Schedule 1, and so on) or you really need to prioritize and/or compromise based on your own personal daily routine. Only you can decide the best action to take here. But the whole point of this step is to make sure your schedule is possible to stick to, so make sure you do that by taking one or both of the options listed above and allowing enough, but not too much time, for each activity.

steps.title: Motivate yourself.
steps.content: Motivate yourself. Be conscious of why you wanted to stick to a schedule in the first place and keep it in your mind. Also be aware of the consequences should you fail to keep a schedule, and the rewards if you are successful. Some pros of keeping a schedule: be more organized, resulting in less stress, can help you be more responsible, make you feel in control of your life, help you be successful in your business, work, school, and/or every day life, etc. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Don't give up.
steps.content: Don't give up. We all fall off the wagon sometimes, so if you don't get it right straight away, don't fret. Identify where you went wrong and try a new strategy. It could take months to get your schedule where you are happy with it and where you can finally stick to it. It's definitely a learn-as-you-go-type experience, but it's well worth it in the end, when you've finally got everything worked out. [8] X Research source
